awd_titl_txt: CAREER:  A novel microbial electrosynthesis platform built on a model electron transfer pathway
awd_abstract_narration:
Two major challenges facing society today are generating fuels and chemicals from sustainable materials, and storing energy produced by solar and wind technologies. Both feats are achieved by bacteria in a process called microbial electrosynthesis, in which bacteria convert carbon dioxide into fuels and chemicals using electricity as a power source. This project will develop bacteria with improved electrosynthesis capability. This project will also train graduate and undergraduate students in synthetic biology to be the next generation of scientists in this emerging field. The educational efforts extend to adult and primary school audiences, to broaden understanding of synthetic biology. 

The proposed work takes a novel approach to enable microbial electrosynthesis by developing a platform for electricity uptake in well-characterized organisms that are amenable to genetic engineering. Preliminary results demonstrate electricity-driven reduction of acetoin to 2,3-butanediol in the electrochemically-active bacterium Shewanella oneidensis MR-1. This is the first-ever demonstration that electricity can be used to generate intracellular reducing power through a defined biochemical pathway. Building on these exciting results, work is proposed to enhance electron transfer rates in this system, connect the system to production of fuels and chemicals in Escherichia coli, and identify the native pathways necessary for electron uptake. This will result in a generalizable platform that can be used to drive a wide range of reduction reactions, including carbon dioxide fixation, and provide a strong foundation for further research.

This CAREER award is supported by the Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental and Transport Systems and the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to develop microbial electrosynthesis technology for energy conversion and storage. Microbial electrosynthesis is the conversion of carbon dioxide into useful products, such as biofuels and bioplastics, using electricity as the power source. Microbial electrosynthesis can help address key energy challenges by providing a way to store electricity in a liquid fuel that is compatible with existing energy infrastructure. In microbial electrosynthesis, bacteria are used to enable the required chemical reactions. We started with a bacterium that can naturally connect chemical reactions with electricity. Normally, this bacterium consumes materials such as sugars and converts them to carbon dioxide, generating electricity as a byproduct. Our goal was to reverse this process and engineer the bacterium to instead take in carbon dioxide and electricity and produce materials.

We added two genes to the bacterium through genetic engineering and created a strain that could use electricity as a power source to drive a targeted chemical reaction. The first generation of bacterial strains created in this project used light and electricity together as power sources and the second generation used electricity only. Both groups of strains may be useful in the future for different applications, especially considering that the first-generation strains can be controlled by light. We also used genetic engineering to identify genes in the bacterium that allow it to perform microbial electrosynthesis. We confirmed the pathway for electricity use and identified bottlenecks currently preventing the system from working faster. This work provides us with ideas for how to further engineer the strains in the future to increase microbial electrosynthesis performance.

We also took steps toward engineering this bacterium to use carbon dioxide as a feedstock, which it cannot naturally do. In nature, only plants and specialized microbes can consume carbon dioxide. Taking inspiration from nature, we took steps to transfer carbon dioxide consuming capabilities from plants into our microbial electrosynthesis strains. We have not yet developed a strain that consumes carbon dioxide but have made important first steps.

 

The experiments in this project were primarily conducted by undergraduate and graduate students at Michigan State University and formed the basis for their training in scientific research under the direction of the principal investigator (professor). The principal investigator also trained over 30 undergraduate students in research through the MSU iGEM team, a competitive team for the iGEM global synthetic biology competition. Many of the students involved in this project have gone on to graduate programs or careers in the biotechnology industry. 

Microbial electrosynthesis addresses multiple biotechnological challenges.
